reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: F.a: Mekong Energy and Ecology Networks work 2018-2019 in Myanmar

description.narrative: MEE Net's 2018-2019 project will continue the work on the three trans-boundary rivers namely Mekong, Salween and Irrawaddy, but will focus more in Myanmar. In Myanmar, civil society has still a chance to influence the key energy policy laws e.g. to support decentralized and sustainable power production on state level. Community-centred strategic environmental assessments (C-SEA) give a good foundation for local democracy and advocacy work initiatives and sustainable natural resources use. Project is climate sustainable (both mitigation and adaptation) and human rights progressive. The key activities in 2018-2019 will be: 1) Maintaining the community-centred strategic environmental assessment approach in Irrawaddy River basin, 2) Continuation of C-SEA work in 12 communities in Ywanngan township of Shan state, 3) Expanding the C-SEA work to Salween river basin and Tanintharyi region, 4) Analysis, legislative support work and media cooperation to push for green energy laws on state level (Shan, maybe also Kayah, Karen) and in Union level, 5) studies and advocacy work related to alternative power development plan, demand side management and other related issues, and 6) monitoring the regional power plans and cooperation with Save the Mekong Coalition. Outcomes wil l be: a) Local communities have been empowered by bottom-up participatory processes and they have developed commons resource governance and practices, b) Amendment for the Myanmar National Electricity Law 2014 has been received by the government, c) State Electricity Law for Shan State is approved and in use, d) Alternative PDP (Power Development Plan) for Myanmar is making the sector more participatory, democratic and sustainable, and e) Development of new energy and economic analysis and materials to sup port campaign against proposed hydropower dams. The main beneficiaries of the project are CSOs and local communities in Myanmar, who are empowered to do advocacy work and protect their environment. Women's participation in activities will be encouraged. I n Myanmar, C-SEA activities reach up to hundred villages and tens of thousands community members. Whole societies benefit from the new progressive laws and renewable and small-scale energy production. MEE Net works closely together with local communities, local NGOs, academics/universities and even with political parties. In the wider Mekong Region, the key partner is the Save the Mekong CSO coalition.
